Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 08:34AM Quaatsi wrote: Hi Jan, I have had 5 total Navalbine.  It wears me out at a deep level. More Nausea and vomiting than on Taxol.  I have lost my appetite half the time maybe? maybe more...  I do get some aching in my head but nothing like you describe.  I got pneumonia twoweeks ago which is going around like crazy the past few weeks but overall my blood counts are terrific and I haven't had to take the neupogen shots.  OH, and very weak legs... I really don't feel like I have much to complain about so...I don't.  I am still riding my horses and while I have my more weak/fatigued days I have many days where life goes on and I can function. I am sorry you are experiencing this but maybe it is just the first injection and your body is saying "WHAAT ... WHAT THE HECK IS THIS NEW STUFF??? I THOUGHT YOU LOVED ME BUT YOU ARE POURING TOXINS INTO OUR BODY" At least I often hear my body say that.... LOL Q

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 07:53AM Quaatsi wrote: oh... funny.. Renee....  Is the cleaning a flurry of energy?  It almsot sounds like a steroid blitz!!  I won;t be getting steroids--one of the many reasons I am going on this is that it does not need steroids or any premeds (that I know of).  I have done pretty well, tolerated well the Taxol. I refused the steroids after the 2nd time.  Since I had NHLymphoma back in 87 (that is 1987 for youngsters...lol), I had an incredible dosage of steroids and a few other drugs that as the chemo was going in I would vomit-- emotional reaction probably.   But a reaction nonetheless. Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 10:07PM Quaatsi wrote: I found the lump, went to my PCP who immediately sent me to get a mammo and by the look on the dr face, I kinda new but then went in for a biopsy.  That was a Tuesday. I was leaving for a trip of a lifetime-- horse camping/riding in Monument Valley. One years planning for it!  I told my pcp to call me and that she would likely have to leave a message.  I told her that since I had been here before (having had lymphoma when I was younger) I would not fall apart and that waiting would be harder than just knowing.  She honored me and left a voice message which I got in the middle of a gorgeous setting-- with my best bud/ horse companion.. Could not imagine a better way to find out horrid news! Q

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 01:58AM Quaatsi wrote: Claire- I was wondering where you where and searched for your posts to sadly find you were so down.  I ish I could drive up there and give you a hug but consider  a cyber one coming your way!   I cannot tell you about AC but I had CHOP years ago which included Adriamycin and Cytoxin as well as a few others so maybe the similar. They were hard and yes, the effects are cumulative.  All you describe is, from my experience, "classic".  You are doing well if you can do anything!!!  I am going through Taxol/Herceptin (5th dose yesterday) and I can only say that compared to the CHOP (with AC in it) this is a cake walk.  I am hopeful you will find it like that as well.   My process is different-- they are concerned about memory issues due to the previous cancer and tx so they started me on TH.  Very soon I will be getting dose dense TCH (cannot have any more Adria, lifetime dose met!) so I suspect the tables will turn and you will be sending me this kind of post.  I wish you the best and know that I am not very far in distance as in spirit! Q
Posts.Title: Feeling pretty low right now claireinaz Terry71

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 08:58AM Quaatsi wrote: I have had both Adriamycin and Cytoxin-- 24 years ago!  Today, my heart is strong-- strong enough to get another whole set of chemo (I can't have AC as there is a lifetime dose which I have certainly had).  Life has been a roller coaster ride but I would not have it any other way.  In the years between my two (different) dx, I have completed a Ph.D., gone on to a four year program in Chinese medicine, started a private practice, adopted a child who has cerebral palsy, built two homes, raced two horses 100 miles.....   I don't think you can worry about future dx-- you just have to make the best decision with the information at hand and give life a chance.  There is so much to life and this is just part of the journey-- go for it!!   You will do fine on AC and if not, they can change it!  Believe in your strength- it is there.   Q
